The answer is, or should be, No. The study of the Bible should be a private activity.

 Not "should be." The answer is no. When I was teaching 7th grade science I made Friday a question day. Any question about any scientific topic was allowed. My purpose was to instruct in what science is and how it works. My promise was to answer the question to the best of my knowledge, and if I didn't have an answer, to research it and present it on Monday. Friday was the day that students wanted to come to school for my class. They actually thought that they were somehow escaping "school work" by asking questions. The usual drill was to try to draw answers from the students themselves. Sometimes, explanations and board diagrams were necessary to lead them to the conclusion. Man! We had fun on Friday.
 
There is quite enough essential information to acquire (and basic skills to master) in school without teachers wasting the students' time inculcating metaphysics and myths.

The "controversy" should be brought up when discussing evolution in school science class.
 
 The kids are likely going to hear about it anyway. They may go to church and be told that all that stuff they are told in science class about evolution is bunk. The kid has to decide which to believe and in the end becomes more cynical for it. (not that it's a bad thing)

They could go to AiG or something similar to look up what the claims of creationism are. Then students would have to figure out which claims are supported by scientific evidence and which are not.
 
 Students could be given an assignment to determine which "theory" is science , if either, and which is not, if either.
